title: new-gps-nurses-call-handlers-join-riverside-medical-practice-musselburgh
story: Two new GPs, two nurse practitioners and two new call handlers have taken up jobs at the surgery since the start of the year, with a further GP due to arrive in the summer and two GPs due tofrom maternity leave.Recruitment for one more GP is ongoing, with a fresh recruitment push due to launch shortly to coincide with new GPs entering the workplace as their training comes to an end.Dr Richard Kitto, a long-standing doctor at the practice, has been made a GP partner.The Courier has previously reported that the practice has come under fire from frustrated patients who have complained about dficulties contacting it to secure appointments.Commenting on the recruitment drive, Dr Richard Fairclough, GP partner, said: ldquoWe must stress to all of our patients and stakeholders in the local community that this remains an exceptionally busy time for general practices all over the country. Our successful recruitment is good news but wersquore now ndash with the exception of one GP, a nurse practitioner and the further call handlers ndash at the limit of the number of people we can employ at the practice yet we estimate that demand for appointments will still outweigh our capacity to provide them.He explained: ldquoWe must therefore continue to stress the urgent need for the full implementation of the  GMS Contract, which lays out the ious types of care due to be removed from the remit of general practice, in order to allow GPs to provide the expert medical care to the local community that we so desperately want to be able to do.He added: ldquoThis is widely recognised to be a challenging time to recruit GPs, with more GPs leaving the Scottish workforce each year than new GPs entering it.ldquoSo given this, wersquore especially delighted to welcome our two new GPs to the practice. Dr Maeve Chestnutt joined us from the Forth Valley Practice in March after relocating to East Lothian and Dr Michael Slowey has joined us last week from a practice in Sussex after locuming with us for a short time.He continued: ldquoWersquod also like to extend warm congratulations to Dr Kitto, who joins myself, Dr Cameron and Dr Stenke as a GP partner.Dr Fairclough said: ldquoTheirs arenrsquot the only new faces at the practice this year. Senior nurse practitioner Chris Gent has joined us as clinical manager from NHS , bringing his considerable clinical and operational experience to Riverside, along with nurse practitioner Sarah Miller.ldquoFinally, wersquore so pleased to welcome a further two new call handlers to our reception team, with more to follow shortly. Being a GP receptionist is such a challenging role, requiring a deep knowledge of how the surgery works, as well as calmness under pressure, and outstanding customer service skills. We know our two new recruits are going to make a great contribution to our now -strong reception team.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-may-10-14-1996-1971-1921
story: A BID to ban booze in a North Berwick park was being proposed, reported the East Lothian Courier on May , .An alcohol exclusion zone could be created in North Berwick as part of a joint police and community initiative to curb underage drinking in town.Plans are underway to ban alcohol from the Lodge Grounds public park ndash a popular haunt for teeny tipplers.A similar scheme is already operating in several streets in Prestonpans ndash the first town in the district to introduce no-go areas for public drinking ndash and police in North Berwick are keen to follow suit.They hope to get the backing of nearby residents and the local community council before taking the idea to East Lothian Licensing Board for formal approval.The matter was discussed at the monthly meeting of North Berwick Community Council on Tuesday.Sergeant Alistair McIntyre warned that banning the drinking of alcohol in the park could push the underage tipplers to other areas of the town, possibly the harbour.FIVE generations of the same family were in attendance at a baptism in Dunbar, told The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .When baby Kathleen Lorimer was baptised in Dunbar Parish Church, her father, grandfather, great-grandfather and great-great-grandfather were there to watch the ceremony.The occasion marked the first time the five generations had gathered together.Baby Kathleen Vanessa is the daughter of Mr Tom Lorimerand his we, Avril.Her grandfather, Mr John Lorimer, gardener, and his we Chris, were there, as were her great-grandfather, Mr Tom Lorimer, a foreman with North Berwick Town Council, and his we Jean.The eldest member of the party was -year-old Mr John Lorimer.TWO men appeared in court after stealing planks of wood from a mine, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .On Friday, at Haddington Sherf Court, Peter Devannah, labourer and John Devannah, miner, both from Tranent, pleaded guilty to having on Saturday rd April, stolen four planks of wood from the pithead of Bankton colliery.The Fiscal said that the accused and another man were seen carrying planks up the railway line from the pit.When the police followed them, they made off.The accused were overtaken, but the third man escaped.They were taken back to the pit and admitted having stolen the wood.They were each fined s.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-14-great-wood-caledon
story: FINN walked by the side of Lochan nam Arm, peering into the water in his search for Robert the Brucersquos sword. Then, something caught his eye.He ran to Izzy: ldquoAunty, aunty, look what I found!He was holding a scarf.ldquoIt was hanging on a tree over there, he said.It was a short neck scarf, with Celtic interlacing design it looked new and unworn, possibly even handmade.ldquoI really love it aunty, can I keep it Izzy pursed her lips in thought.ldquoI dunno, Finn, someone may have dropped it and another person found it and placed it on the tree to keep it safe. Perhaps one of those walkers earlier. Maybe they will come back and look for it Finn wasnrsquot even half listening. He put the scarf on and rushed to the loch side to look at his reflection.ldquoIt would be safer round my neck surely  he called out.As he arranged the scarf, a folded piece of paper fell to the ground and landed by Finnrsquos feet. He picked it up, unfolded it and ran to Izzy, very excited.ldquoLook, the scarf is for me! he exclaimed.A worried look came over Izzyrsquos face as Finn handed her the piece of paper. There were beautully drawn Celtic designs, with images of what looked like faeries hiding in a wood.There was also a sleeping dragon curled round a heart shape in which there was handwriting: ldquoIf you have found me, and you like me, then Irsquom yours. Keep me safe, until itrsquos time to give me away.Izzy looked at Finn, nodded and smiled. ldquoSo it seems.ldquoI will never give this away! he insisted. He looked around at the trees and ed the gaze to his aunt.ldquoMaybe yoursquore right, aunty, maybe fairies do exist after all, at least here we are in the Highlands after all.He thought for a moment. ldquoOr maybe itrsquos just someone kind who likes to give presents.Finn headed back to the tree where hersquod found the scarf. He arranged twigs and broken bits of heather on the ground next to the tree and beckoned his aunt to come see.She looked down at what hersquod done. She didnrsquot immediately see it, but then realised that the twigs and heather formed letters.He carefully read it: ldquoThank you.ldquoThatrsquos lovely Finn, whoever left the scarf will see this and be very happy, Irsquom sure of it.Izzy looked up to the sky. The predicted rain was going to hold off.ldquoFinn, she said hesitantly, ldquowould you be up for a bit of an adventure ldquoYou mean a walk, donrsquot you ldquoKind of, aye, but this is to a place I have never been before, although Irsquove often seen it from a distance.ldquoHow far  asked Finn.Izzy pointed: ldquoJust there, where those old trees are. Itrsquos a small remnant of the old Caledonian forest, Irsquove often wanted to visit it but have never had the opportunity. Itrsquos not so far, but it might be a bit dficult to reach, Irsquove never explored it before.Finn wasnrsquot sure.Izzy helped him decide: ldquoIt might have a connection to the original Merlin.That sold it to him.ldquoWell, I have my boots, he smiled, ldquocan I lead the way So they set off in the direction of Coille Coire Chuic, a small remnant of the ancient Caledonian forest. Izzy let Finn decide on the route and as they neared the wood they arrived at the River Cononish. There was no obvious and safe way to cross, but Izzy was sure there was a small bridge downriver.The route got increasingly boggy and Izzy suspected Finn may want to give up, but instead he took the role of leader seriously and carefully planned each step, identying dryer patches and helping his aunt. They made slow progress, but with much hilarity as they balanced on small tufts of dry land surrounded by bog myrtle.Finn paused and listened. The noise of a waterfall could be heard ahead and he aimed for it. Izzy lagged behind to take in the beauty of the heather, which carpeted the ground with a blaze of purple and pink. The old Scots pines on the other side of the river looked magnicent, framed by the mountains beyond.She caught up with Finn, who was sitting on a rock watching the waterfall. It cascaded into a hidden pool, where the water twirled and bubbled asin a giant cauldron. Scots pine trees stood guard on the edge of it, one growing precariously from the overhanging rocks, its trunk curving upwards so its higher branches reached the sunlight. A gnarled rowan with vivid berries grew from the rocks on the other side, while on the opposite bank birch trees clung onto the steep side of the river, bent over like weeping willows.Finn wanted to sit awhile and so Izzy took it as an opportunity to make a brew for them both. He was beginning to understand that using her small camping stove was an important ritual for his aunt: the hissing sound, the waiting, the trail of steam, the anticipation it made a warm feeling, turned a wild place into home.They sipped tea together and shared well-earned snacks. Finn waited, expecting his aunt to tell a story. Finally, she did.ldquoSee that giant boulder over there, Finn, it was dropped by the giants who sculpted this land many years ago.ldquoLike with Samsonrsquos stone we saw Izzy nodded.Finn raised a cynical eyebrow and half a smile.ldquoHuge giants, Finn, a race called the Fomorians. The legend says they emerged from the sea long ago ndash grotesque troll-like creatures, incredibly powerful and cruel. Two of them made Rannoch Moor their home and they terrorised the people for miles around, destroying homes and taking livestock.ldquoNobody knew what to do, even the bravest and best warriors were defeated by them, ripped apart without mercy. Then a young lad about your age had his home destroyed by one of the giants, and in his grief he decided to rid the land of them.ldquoBut how could he do thateven the best warriors couldnrsquot Izzy gave him a wry smile, which he knew meant that was a good question and that she was just about to answer it.ldquoThe lad was wise. He had noticed how the two giants argued with each other about who was the stronger.ldquoSo he got them to fight each other ldquoKind of, he persuaded them to have a competition to see who could throw a stone furthest. They began hurling bigger and bigger stones, then they tore chunks of rock off the mountain sides. Soon the land was littered with boulders, and after three days the two giants were utterly exhausted.ldquoThen the young lad told one of the giants he had won, for he knew this would cause a fight. And so it did.ldquoThe giants fought each other with fury, using up what energy they had left. Finally, one gave the other a fatal blow, but it was the last thing he did, as he collapsed with total exhaustion.ldquoThey had killed each other ldquoYes, smiled Izzy, filling her cup with more tea and raising it. ldquoThatrsquos why the land around here is littered with all these huge stones.ldquoI know giants are mythological, aunty.Izzy sipped some tea.ldquoDepends what kind of giants you mean.Finn looked at the boulder.ldquoThe next tale is the gt of the sun, continued Izzy.ldquoAfter the death of the giants the land was bathed in sunshine, bringing new le.It became a green world, grass and plants grew, then trees arrived. The ancestors of this tree were first to arrive, she pointed to the nearby silver birch.ldquoOthers followed: the rowan, the aspen, alder and even oak. But it was these trees which made the forest canopy: Scots pines, also called Caledonian pines, an old name given to them by the Romans. Arenrsquot they a beautul tree Finn peered at the Scots pines around them.ldquoCreatures filled the forest with their songs, their roars, their grunting and howling the birds, bears, wolves, elk, deer and boar. Seven thousand years ago, where we sit we would have been amidst the Caledonian forest in its prime. Those trees over there are the descendants of that forest. If you sit with them and feel their presence, they will tell you their stories.Finn chuckled at his aunt, then explained why. ldquoYou are like Yoda! He defensively held up his hands to explain: ldquoNot the way you look, I mean the way you speak about things.Finn was a Star Wars fan. He had all three films on video at home and knew much of the dialogue by heart. He spoke to Izzy, mimicking Yodarsquos voice: ldquoSearch the force, le creates it, makes it grow, its energy surrounds us and binds us, luminous beings are we. Finn gently pinched Izzy on the shoulder, saying: ldquoNot this crude matter. You must feel the force around you, the tree, the rock, everywhere.Izzy laughed out loud, feeling rather flattered to be compared to one of Finnrsquos screen heroes. She thanked him for the compliment.Finn looked over at the old Scots pines on the other side of the river. He knew his aunt wanted to reach them and they were tantalisingly close, yet the river was too dangerous to cross.ldquoLetrsquos find a way to get there, he ventured.They packed up and followed the river, eventually finding a place to cross. They sat amidst the flowering heather under the canopy of old trees, near a clearing so a light breeze kept the midges at bay. As promised, Izzy spun legends of Merlin, but also other tales connected to the ancient forest: of Lailoken, the Picts and St Columba, and the sad tale of the last wolf. Finn added tales of his own, about Jedi Knights and what he could remember of the story of Tam Linn. The forest was both their theatre and audience. But there was a sense of melancholy in this wood, for something was missing: it was bereft of young trees. The old pines were missing their children.The walk back was much quicker and they arrived back at the car tired, but with a sense of achievement. It felt asthey had been in a dferent world.ldquoCan we camp tonight aunty  asked Finn. ldquoAnd have a campfire like the first night ldquoLetrsquos see how the weather holds and how we feel later, she replied, keeping options open.Food was now a priority and Izzy was keen to get away from the busyness of Tyndrum. Soon they were on their way, heading for Loch Tulla, where she planned to make their tea. She knew Ewen would already be at the Bridge of Orchy. What she didnrsquot know was his mum was with him, Finnrsquos grandmother, whom Finn had loved so much.She was waiting with her son in his car, literally trembling with emotion, desperate to see her beloved grandson, whom she hadnrsquot seen for more than four and a half years.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, , ,  and .

title: section-a1-closed-overnight-later-month-work-overhead-lines
story: Roadworks on the A, between the Thistly Cross and Abbotsview junctions, mean that the road will be closed from pm on May  until am the following day.A spokesman for Bear Scotland confirmed that work was being carried out by Keltbray on behalf of ScottishPower.He said that Keltbray had produced a statement, which reads: ldquoKeltbray, on behalf of ScottishPower, are carrying out essential work on a section of overhead lines between May  at pm to May  at am which will result in the closure of a section of the A.ldquoThis will include work on the high voltage and low voltage networks, changing electricity poles and overhead power cables.ldquoWe are replacing and refurbishing equipment which is coming to the end of its serviceable le, which is essential works to make sure we maintain a good quality of supply for our customers.ldquoA ersion route will be in place.ldquoAccess for emergency vehicles will be maintained at all times.

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

title: historic-dunbar-methodist-church-saved-public-use
story: Dunbar Methodist Church ndash the oldest existing Methodist church in Scotland ndash dates back to .However, in , the congregations of Dunbar Methodist Church and nearby St Annersquos Scottish Episcopal Church merged and began meeting at the latter.The Victoria Street building was later sold, with developer Monkscroft Properties Limited keen to ensure that ldquothe building remained in use as a public space and as an asset for the community of Dunbar.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department has given the go-ahead to change the building into a venue for weddings, s and community use.Ewan McIntyre, who is behind the scheme, was delighted to see progress being made.He said: ldquoThe best reason to buy the building was to make sure it did not get turned into housing. It is part of the fabric of Dunbar.Minimal changes are planned for the building, with replacement steps outside.The main church space has capacity for about  people for worship, with the developers looking to host ldquosmall and intimate weddings, with a reduced capacity of up to  people seated for lunch or dinner and up to  people in total for ceremonies and celebrations.Stained glass windows have been repaired, while other decoration has been completed inside the building.Members of the public will get the chance to look around the venue on May  and  at an open door event.However, the proposals did not win favour with everyone in the town.The planning department received three letters objecting to the plans, with concerns that there would be loud music played at the venue, disturbance with people congregating before, during and after events, and worries about where people attending events would park their cars.During the planning process, the applicants highlighted ldquorelationships with neighbours are crucial to the success of the venue and the utmost care will be given to managing guests and noise.Dunbarrsquos community council was among those who backed the proposals when they were first lodged with the local authority in summer last year.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, was pleased the scheme was progressing.She highlighted that the building was not listed and it could have been demolished or transformed to make way for housing.She was pleased the building would remain in community use.Mrs Swan said: ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled.ldquoI know that the Methodist church building, when it was a place of worship and dwindling congregation, was an uphill struggle to keep the building in good repair.ldquoIt is fantastic that it has got a new owner and wonderful it is being kept as a place of public assembly.

title: tranent-fundraiser-taking-two-double-marathons-walk-walk
story: Margaret MacLeod, , took up marathon running at the age of , and has now completed six official Walk The Walk lsquoOver The Moonrsquo events, which see participants complete  miles in less than  hours.While walkers of the virtual Over The Moon this year are being given a longer, -hour time limit, Margaret has decided to push herself to stay within  hours.The Tranent resident, who will be completing the virtual event on Saturday, said: ldquoItrsquos a huge challenge.ldquoI can walk a marathon in just under six hoursIrsquom really pushing it, and I can run one in just under five itrsquos like running a marathon at your top speed the whole time.Last year, the Walk The Walk fundraiser was cancelled entirely and this yearrsquos has been forced to go virtual, due to Covid ndash but that hasnrsquot stopped the intrepid Winton Close resident, who last year walked  laps of her house for the challenge.She said of this yearrsquos event: ldquoI thoughtI did laps nearby, I could get people to come and walk a lap with me.ldquoAnd before I knew it, I had a wee team!Margaret, a receptionist in the investment industry by day, will be joined on her double marathon journey round the .-mile route by  dferent friends, who will each complete a lap of the route with her.This year, the theme of the event is lsquoOut Of This Worldrsquo, which would usually be illustrated by participantsrsquo decorated bras. But, says Margaret, she is ldquothe worst sewer ever.She told the Courier: ldquoI have no imagination so my bra has just got a wee bit of fringing and some wee glitzy bits. Itrsquos just glammed.And Margaretrsquos two adult sons have mixed feelings about their inspirational mumrsquos athletic achievements. While one ran with her for her first marathon ndash ldquoa challenge for my th birthday according to Margaret ndash the other is not quite as hands-on.She said: ldquoMy younger one ran with me dressed as Elsa from Frozen, so hersquos extremely supportive but the older one just grunts at me: lsquoGood on you, mum.rsquoBut Margaret is pushing ahead with her challenge ndash inspired and supported, she says, by Haddington Running Club ndash despite her own reservations about walking in her bra in daylight.She said: ldquoIrsquom putting myself out there for breast cancer. story: Police Scotland has revealed plans to stop staffing the cells at the station, making it an lsquoancillaryrsquo centre which will only be used during major events or as back-up.The move will mean people arrested in East Lothian and Midlothian, who would have been taken into custody in the Midlothian station now face being transported to St Leonardrsquosin Edinburgh for lock-up.A meeting of East Lothianrsquos Police, Fire and Community Safety Scrutiny Committee, was told that the proposals would free up two additional local police officers for the county.However, concerns were raised by councillors about the additional journey time it would take for officers to transport people in custody to the Edinburgh station.Suzie Mertes, from Police Scotlandrsquos Criminal Justice Services ision, said that the number of people being taken into custody in Scotland had halved from , to , in recent timesand changes were being made as part of an annual review.She told the committee that providing custody services at St Leonardrsquos would be better for prisoners who might be vulnerable as more support services were available and would benefit local officers who were currently drafted in to ldquobackfill for custody officers when they were on leave.It was not made clear whether the decision to take custody officers away from Dalkeith would see opening hours of the station reduced or changed.However, Ms Mertes stressed that the custody facilities would not close completely and would be available for major events in the area or times when it was felt they were needed.And she said that current custody staff based at Dalkeith would be given the option to transfer their services to support local policing.She added: ldquoIn terms of Dalkeith, should someone need to be brought in for an interview it will be open.ldquoThis is a flexible model that will allow us to push and pull resources into Dalkeith when needed.Concerns were raised about the additional journey time for officers transporting prisoners to St Leonardrsquos for custody however, Ms Mertes said that the benefits outweighed the disadvantages, pointing out that officers could sometimes find themselves manning empty cells at Dalkeith when they could be spending time on local policing.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, committee convenor, said that the move could prove beneficial to those who found themselves spending a night in the cells as well.And the decision was welcomed by the committee convenor to downgrade Dalkeithrsquos custody centre from a full-time operation to lsquoancillaryrsquo.He said: ldquoThere are some concerns that there is movement towards the centre of Edinburgh but there may be some benefit for the poor souls taken into custody.ldquoIf they are released from Dalkeith, getting back to North Berwick is an absolute nightmare, whereasthey are released from St Leonardrsquos, getting back to North Berwick is substantially easier.
